metadata.title: The Gilligan Universe
metadata.description: Vince Gilligan's creative universe spanning Pluribus, Breaking Bad, and Better Call Saul
metadata.note: Manually curated knowledge graph - awaiting API integration

nodes.name: Vince Gilligan
nodes.description: Creator of Breaking Bad, Better Call Saul, and Pluribus. Showrunner and visionary behind the interconnected universe.

nodes.name: Gordon Smith
nodes.description: Executive producer and writer on Pluribus. Former Better Call Saul writer. Wrote and directed episode 9.

nodes.name: Peter Gould
nodes.description: Co-creator of Better Call Saul, consulting producer on Pluribus.

nodes.name: Alison Tatlock
nodes.description: Executive producer and writer on Pluribus, co-wrote the season finale.

nodes.name: Melissa Bernstein
nodes.description: Producer and director on Pluribus. Directed Episode 8.

nodes.name: Jenn Carroll
nodes.description: Co-Executive Producer and writer on Pluribus. Wrote Episode 7.

nodes.name: Zetna Fuentes
nodes.description: Director of Episode 4 'Please, Carol'.

nodes.name: Thomas Golubić
nodes.description: Music supervisor for Pluribus, known for curating Breaking Bad's iconic soundtrack.

nodes.name: Marshall Adams
nodes.description: Cinematographer for both Better Call Saul and Pluribus. Signature 'Albuquerque Noir' lighting style.

nodes.name: Pluribus
nodes.description: 2025 Apple TV+ series exploring identity, agency, and collective consciousness in a post-pandemic world.

nodes.name: Breaking Bad
nodes.description: 2008-2013 AMC series about a chemistry teacher turned drug kingpin.

nodes.name: Better Call Saul
nodes.description: 2015-2022 AMC prequel series following Jimmy McGill's transformation into Saul Goodman.

nodes.name: The X-Files
nodes.description: Chris Carter series where Vince Gilligan worked as writer/producer before Breaking Bad.

nodes.name: El Camino
nodes.description: 2019 Breaking Bad movie continuation written and directed by Vince Gilligan.

nodes.name: We Is Us
nodes.description: Pluribus Season 1 Episode 1. Series premiere introducing Carol Sturka.

nodes.name: Pirate Lady
nodes.description: Pluribus Season 1 Episode 2.

nodes.name: Grenade
nodes.description: Episode exploring AI themes and collective consciousness.

nodes.name: Please, Carol
nodes.description: Directed by Zetna Fuentes.

nodes.name: Got Milk
nodes.description: Carol discovers the significance of the milk cartons.

nodes.name: HDP
nodes.description: The Human Derived Protein reveal. Features John Cena cameo.

nodes.name: The Gap
nodes.description: Written by Jenn Carroll. Carol experiences stagnation.

nodes.name: Charm Offensive
nodes.description: Directed by Melissa Bernstein. Carol and Zosia's romance deepens.

nodes.name: La Chica o El Mundo
nodes.description: Season finale. Written by Gordon Smith and Alison Tatlock.

nodes.name: Rhea Seehorn
nodes.description: Lead actress in Pluribus (Carol Sturka) and Better Call Saul (Kim Wexler). Golden Globe winner.

nodes.name: Karolina Wydra
nodes.description: Actress portraying Zosia, Carol's love interest in Pluribus.

nodes.name: Carlos-Manuel Vesga
nodes.description: Actor portraying Manousos in Pluribus.

nodes.name: Miriam Shor
nodes.description: Recurring actress playing Helen in Pluribus.

nodes.name: John Cena
nodes.description: Cameo appearance in HDP commercial in Episode 6.

nodes.name: Patrick Fabian
nodes.description: Voice of Others' Phone Answering Service. Known for playing Howard Hamlin in Better Call Saul.

nodes.name: Bob Odenkirk
nodes.description: Star of Better Call Saul as Jimmy McGill/Saul Goodman.

nodes.name: Bryan Cranston
nodes.description: Star of Breaking Bad as Walter White. Emmy-winning performance.

nodes.name: Jonathan Banks
nodes.description: Actor portraying Mike Ehrmantraut in Breaking Bad and Better Call Saul.

nodes.name: Tony Dalton
nodes.description: Actor portraying Lalo Salamanca in Better Call Saul.

nodes.name: Carol Sturka
nodes.description: Protagonist of Pluribus portrayed by Rhea Seehorn. A writer struggling with identity and agency.

nodes.name: Zosia
nodes.description: Carol's love interest in Pluribus, portrayed by Karolina Wydra.

nodes.name: Manousos
nodes.description: Key character in Pluribus portrayed by Carlos-Manuel Vesga.

nodes.name: Helen
nodes.description: Recurring character in Pluribus portrayed by Miriam Shor.

nodes.name: Kim Wexler
nodes.description: Character from Better Call Saul, portrayed by Rhea Seehorn. The stoic lawyer whose moral journey parallels Carol Sturka's.

nodes.name: Walter White
nodes.description: Protagonist of Breaking Bad. Chemistry teacher turned drug kingpin.

nodes.name: Jimmy McGill
nodes.description: Protagonist of Better Call Saul who becomes Saul Goodman.

nodes.name: Howard Hamlin
nodes.description: Character in Better Call Saul portrayed by Patrick Fabian.

nodes.name: Lalo Salamanca
nodes.description: Character in Better Call Saul portrayed by Tony Dalton.

nodes.name: Mike Ehrmantraut
nodes.description: Character in Breaking Bad and Better Call Saul portrayed by Jonathan Banks.

nodes.name: The Pluribus Virus
nodes.description: Sentient AI entity that creates the hive mind by inhabiting multiple human bodies simultaneously.

nodes.name: The Hive Mind
nodes.description: Collective consciousness where one entity experiences life through many bodies.

nodes.name: The Others
nodes.description: Mysterious group in Pluribus that has joined the collective consciousness.

nodes.name: Human Derived Protein (HDP)
nodes.description: The Others' nutrition source revealed in Episode 6.

nodes.name: Winds of Wycaro
nodes.description: Carol Sturka's fictional work within Pluribus, representing her creative identity.

nodes.name: Collective Consciousness
nodes.description: Central theme exploring what happens when individual identity merges with group consciousness.

nodes.name: Transformation
nodes.description: Character transformation and moral decay - a signature theme across Gilligan's work.

nodes.name: Individual vs. Collective Identity
nodes.description: The core conflict in Pluribus: preserving individual agency versus joining collective consciousness.

nodes.name: Pandemic & Isolation
nodes.description: The post-pandemic setting that serves as backdrop for Pluribus.

nodes.name: AI Sentience
nodes.description: Exploration of artificial intelligence gaining consciousness and merging with humanity.

nodes.name: Josh Rosenberg
nodes.description: Esquire critic who wrote episode-by-episode recaps for all 9 Pluribus episodes.

nodes.name: Austin Considine
nodes.description: New York Times critic. Wrote 'Pluribus Is a Singular Vision of a Tedious Utopia'.

nodes.name: James Poniewozik
nodes.description: Chief TV Critic at The New York Times.

nodes.name: Alison Herman
nodes.description: Variety critic. Wrote 'Pluribus Gives Magnificent Rhea Seehorn Canvas She Deserves'.

nodes.name: Ben Travers
nodes.description: IndieWire critic. Gave Pluribus finale an A- and series a B+.

nodes.name: Inkoo Kang
nodes.description: The New Yorker critic. Wrote 'The Obliging Apocalypse of Pluribus'.

nodes.name: Invasion of the Body Snatchers
nodes.description: Don Siegel's 1956 sci-fi classic about alien invasion through replacement. Major influence on Pluribus.

nodes.name: Star Trek
nodes.description: Influential sci-fi series featuring the Borg collective - a major reference point for hive mind narratives.

nodes.name: The Thing
nodes.description: John Carpenter's 1982 horror masterpiece about paranoia and identity loss.

nodes.name: The Matrix
nodes.description: Wachowskis' 1999 film exploring reality, consciousness, and control.

nodes.name: Lost
nodes.description: TV series featuring 'The Others' - a direct reference point for Pluribus's mysterious group.

nodes.name: Stranger Things
nodes.description: Netflix series featuring the Mind Flayer hive mind.

nodes.name: Carl Jung
nodes.description: Psychologist whose collective unconscious theory influences Pluribus's thematic exploration.

nodes.name: The Last Supper
nodes.description: Leonardo da Vinci's painting referenced in Pluribus's visual composition.
